summary: This document contains notes from an April 21, 2021 call with Dr. Lisa Rocchio, an expert witness, outlining her qualifications and the topics of her expected testimony. It focuses on the psychological dynamics of childhood sexual abuse, trauma, memory, disclosure patterns, and the concept of complex trauma, particularly in the context of manipulation and coercion within established relationships.

persons.name: Dr. Lisa Rocchio
persons.context: Dr. Rocchio is being prepared as an expert witness. The document details her extensive training, experience, and research in trauma, forensic psychology, and childhood sexual abuse, and outlines the topics on which she will testify.

events.title: Expert Witness Preparation Call
events.description: A call was held with Dr. Lisa Rocchio to outline her qualifications and the scope of her expert testimony regarding the psychology of trauma and childhood sexual abuse.

keyFacts: The expert, Dr. Lisa Rocchio, emphasizes that sexual abuse of minors frequently occurs through manipulation and coercion within an established relationship over time, not just forcible rape.
Dr. Rocchio challenges the language that victims are 'susceptible,' stating it is more accurate to say they are 'targeted,' shifting the onus away from the victim.

The testimony will cover 'complex trauma,' a condition resulting from prolonged childhood abuse by caregivers or trusted adults, which leads to more severe outcomes than PTSD, including distorted perceptions of the perpetrator.
The document notes that nondisclosure, incremental disclosure, and secrecy are common among abuse victims due to fear, shame, humiliation, and fear of not being believed or retaliation.

Dr. Rocchio's qualifications include training psychiatric residents at Brown University, serving on the APA Ethics Committee, and running a forensic practice evaluating survivors of sexual abuse and trauma.
